ANSWER: The GIF! The first images on the web were all GIFs, and Mosaic, the first GUI web browser, didn't originally support JPEGs. 

 GIFs were invented in 1987; JPEGs in 1991-ish.

1091441097589452800.text:
Study: people have a bias towards giving higher ratings over time. Holds for everything from Wine Spectator to job candidates.

Why? If the process of rating feels easier, as it will over time, you judge the object of your rating as higher quality. 

Important for interviewing!

1063709379948556288.text: "It is worthwhile trying to discover more about the world, even if this only teaches us how little we know. It might do us good to remember from time to time that, while differing widely in the various little bits we know, in our infinite ignorance we are all equal." -Karl Popper

1062450826860318721.text:
Oh, and John D. Rockefeller, the oil magnate whose kerosene gas lit every home before the spread of the lightbulb, decided to install both oil AND electric lights for his new mansion. 

Imagine Steve Jobs owning both an iPhone and a Pixel... wild.

1062450826143129600.text:
Also, Edison publicly electrocuted a circus elephant to death (?!) using AC power for the same reason: he wanted to spread the lie that AC was more dangerous than DC so he could make more $$.

(We're lucky our geniuses today just smoke weed and say dumb things on Twitter.)

1062450825509797888.text: Case in point: Thomas Edison was so obsessed with winning the standards war between his direct current (DC) and Tesla's alternating current (AC) that *he built the world's first electric chair*... and attached it to AC power to show how dangerous Tesla's system was.

1062450824620597249.text:
Second topic of my "consumers are afraid of everything" research: 

electricity. 

The adoption of electricity was WILD, y'all. Thomas Edison was apparently a huge jerk.

1057500045577207808.text: Also, early elevator users feared: suffocation, claustrophobia, and "elevator sickness" (defined as "dizziness to the head and sometimes a nausea to the stomach"), the latter of which can only be cured by "placing the head and the shoulders against the car frame."

1057500044591554562.text: Turns out early elevator companies suffered due to their perceived similarity to mines, which were actually super dangerous (~20% of mine elevators broke as late as 1872).

1057500043584909312.text:
I am a recently ordained history nerd -- because I realized that business is basically just applied history.

Current obsession: how the general public responded to "new" technology during past waves of innovation. I just read a book about elevators... legit super interesting.
